job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: I enjoyed teaching students and helping them succeed in the courses I taught. I gained a lot of useful experience developing my communication skills. The instructors in my department were very supportive and backed me up when handling difficult situations with students. I felt empowered to do my job and they gave me a space where I could take ownership of my work and perform a job that I could be proud of.
cons: Unfortunately the pay was lacking compared to the other universities in Chicago, but everywhere else in the city is a private school so that may explain (not excuse) it. I heard of students struggling to pay bills with the pay they were receiving (I was fortunate to have a higher stipend based the department I worked in). It's bad enough that the students will go on strike to demand higher pay every few years (many instructors also support this and also will protest for higher pay in their union as well). You may deal with disgruntled undergraduate students as a TA who are upset due to factors that are out of your control (though in some ways this was a positive experience in that it helped me develop skills in handling such situations as stated above). There were sometimes communication issues with instructors as to expectations but I think a large part of it was due to having to adapt different teaching modalities during COVID times and then having to transition back to in-person teaching.

review_title: Great university to start a career, horrible if you stay
pros: Great university to start your career in higher education, college accessibility, or the public sector. If you are starting your career, this is a great institution to work for, but I don't recommend staying for a long time. The biggest pro: if you are planning to earn a degree (typically a master's degree), the cost of your education is basically free (limited to a certain amount of $ per year), as long as you are a full-time, eligible employee. Another pro: if you are a full-time, eligible employee & have a child attending the university or another public university, your child can get 50% tuition waiver and save a lot of money.
cons: The health benefits are limited, basic, and expensive, regardless of the plan. There is only 3 options of the university pension, and they don't really provide a matching % for retirement. If you work hard, build a professional network, and perform well in your role, your opportunity to advance and earn monetary rewards is very, very minimum. Most promotions and advancement opportunities are through favoritism or university politics. The university's departments also work in silos and don't work collaboratively as best as they can

job_title: Adjunct ESL Instructor in Chicago, IL
pros:
-Hourly pay rate for adjuncts is good at 36/hr. 
-The people I work with are excellent - highly qualified, fun, willing to help you out and go the extra mile
-My department is doing everything it can to make things good for us - even for adjuncts. However, they're limited by upper admin and HR
cons:
-There doesn't seem to be much hope for full-time employment in the UIC professor world. I have been there on and off for 3 years, and it's just looking worse. They continue to add to the number of adjuncts working fewer than 30 hours per week, while upper admin makes 6 figures.
-HR is an absolute and total nightmare. I went 2 months more than once without getting paid. Someone made a clerical error, and if it weren't for an employee breaking the rules, I would've had to pay over $500/mo. in part-time benefits...at $36/hour, part-time...
-I've noticed that contracts are changing in a way that does not benefit the instructors. I used to be on a % contract, but am now on an hourly one with more experience and responsibility. That's about a 35% pay cut.
-If you have more than 4-5 students as an instructor, you will be doing more work than you'll get paid for.

review_title: Only 37% of advancement team said they're not looking elsewhere due to toxic culture
pros:
Wonderful university mission
Alumni and donors are caring even if not in position to give
Student body is incredibly talented and diverse
cons:
In a recent survey between 60-70% of the staff indicated that they feel like they're not valued and have shared that they're looking elsewhere due to a toxic work culture. 

Only 36% said "advancement leadership values them as individuals" (4% strongly agree, 14% 18% somewhat agree) while 57% felt this was false (10% somewhat disagree, 18% disagree, 29% strongly disagree) and 7% were unsure.

To the question "I have considered leaving UIC because of the culture in OVCA (Advancement office)" 57% said they agreed (21% strongly agree, 16% agree, 13% somewhat agree) and only 37% said they disagreed (7% somewhat disagree, 25% disagree, and 5% strongly disagree) and 7% were unsure/didn't know.

Many people used the free response question to call out the current leadership and/or to express that even in an anonymous survey they didn't feel comfortable avoiding retaliation for giving honest feedback.

A fake postdoc position to save money on a regular administrative worker salary and benefits. No opportunity or support to do research in a postdoctoral research position, no mentor, no grant experience of any kind, no writing/publishing experience of any kind - able to do any of this on my complete own on ONE day during the week, otherwise not allowed to write for publication, work on research or grants (which without a mentor and support is impossible anyway), not allowed to work on research with research assistants. Highly administrative/secretarial work, no possibility to even observe or participate in any research activity since the organization does not conduct any research at all. 
The position is a joke. 
Lack of support to try to get any research related opportunities, impossible to become a part of any of the existing elites, poor benefits, nobody cares that the position is a mistake either. This should not be legal.

job_title: Research Associate I in Chicago, IL
pros:
Coming out of undergrad, you learn a lot and polish a lot of laboratory skills that makes you more confident for your next job.
If you're looking for a gateway into graduate school, want to make connections for it, and regularly attend meetings in an advanced scientific environment, this is a great place for it.
You can leave whenever experiments for the day is done, it is an hourly position so you don't need to stay a full 8 hours and you can always ask to take a day off if you want (may vary from PI to PI though).
cons:
You are paid minimum university wage without any chance of a raise or any sort of benefit (not even a holiday bonus) despite the advanced level of work you are doing.
Some PI's are understaffed leaving you to pick up a lot of the work as the budget for workers like me are dependent on the grants your PI get for that year.
In my case, I'm left doing much more animal work than I had known I would be doing and I'm the only one to do it.
Most people are very unfriendly, I try to walk with my head up and great others as I walk past them in the halls whether or not I know them and almost everyone, besides the janitors and postmen and women I greet, keep their head down and look away.
There is quite a toxic work environment with a lot of senior researchers arguing and some cases shouting at each other over disagreements about sharing data, authorships, or co-authorships. As a research associate, you aren't really a part of that but hearing a lot of this doesn't exactly boost morale. 
Covid restrictions are too overbearing. Most people in my department are vaccinated but despite this, we are still forced to wear masks, do biweekly saliva tests, get scanned for out temperature every day and check in, and swear online that we don't have any symptoms every morning.
The price of parking at any UIC lot is unacceptable at around $500 every few months. If you work on the west side of campus, you can park at the Juvenile Center which is about a 10 minute walk away from some of the buildings for $2 a day but other than that, your left on your own and that includes the daily parking fee.

review_title: Receive funding while pursuing a MSc degree
pros: Research assistantships allow students to receive funding while pursuing an MSc or PhD degree. Monthly stipends are complemented by a tuition waiver that includes medical insurance. cons: The position is not guaranteed to be renewed and often doesn't last longer than one semester for MSc students. On the other hand, it is possible to find a different research topic and start a new research assistant position. Exploring different fields allows a student to form a more comprehensive idea about his interests for the future.

review_title: Excellent place to get a free education, great health/retirement benefits, low salary, incompetent coworkers/management
pros:
- Tuition waiver to finish a master degree, will work around your work schedule.
- 1 year: 24 vacation days (accumulated to max of 48 days), 25 sick days.
- Lay back environment, you can surf the web the entire day
- Can't get fired easily, the longer you stay the harder it is to get rid of you.
- Health, dental, life, vision, mandatory retirement fund (SURS), optional 403(b), optional 457(b), etc.
- Should be easy to get vacation approved
- Whatever you need for the office you can get, especially with a budget surplus, before the end of the fiscal year. SPEND! SPEND! SPEND!
cons:
- Incompetent coworkers and management (pushes the work onto the more competent workers)
- Tons of work, if you feel like working in this environment
- Vague deadlines, since management doesn't set firm deadlines and deadlines tend to be forgotten by management
- Little to no training
- The lower your salary, the more work you get.
- The more competent you are, the more work you get.
- Low salary, your salary = x, your boss salary = 1.5x, your boss' boss salary = 2x, your boss' boss' boss salary = 3x
- High bureaucracy (it takes 4 people and weeks/months to purchase 1 item for the office)
- Lack of supplies
- Little to no raises in salary
- Vague work responsibilities

review_title: Love what I do now but it didn't start that way.
pros:
These pros are all from my current department: flexibility, allowed to work on own with minimal supervision. 
Overall about UIC: Once you are full-time the benefits package is really can't be matched in the the private sector. You get plenty of vacation and sick time. Health insurance is also not too shabby.
cons:
The raises are pretty awful. This year we got a departmental 2.5% across the board and that was after years of minimal to no raises. Massive cuts to possibly take into effect next year. Job instability is highly probable.
In previous department which was considered University Administration there was a departmental merger. Employees were expected to learn 2 job functions yet no classification nor a pay increase was given. When staffed complained to HR the response was either you like it and deal with it or you move on. Staff and faculty are also not the most professional. Be prepared for all levels of education and all levels of rudeness within and outside your department. Poor work environment (ugly/run-down offices) and poor morale among employees. Training is also not uniform. Expect to get trained by 10 individuals all training you in the most haphazard of ways.
