review_title: The easiest job you'll ever hate
job_title: Senior Communications Officer in Chicago, IL
pros: You won't break a sweat here.  Lethargic atmosphere with extremely low expectations.  No one comes in on time, no one stays late, and if you come into the office on the weekend you will be the only person there.  It's relatively easy to run circles around or outshine your co-workers if that's your aim, although it won't get you anywhere in terms of promotions or compensation.  It's not uncommon for employees to have second or third jobs that they do at their desks.
cons: Ridiculously bureaucratic with lots of state-mandated big brother oversight on things such as ethics and attendance—although none of it is enforced.  (We’re assured by management that no one even looks at the stuff; we just have to do it.)  The system is clogged by an inordinate amount of needless management and supervisory positions, most filled with career deadwood who come in only long enough to make sure they’ll still qualify for their hefty pensions—the kind of manager who doesn’t understand how to use Excel so asks for everything in Word.  You can bet your supervisor couldn’t do your job.  Rank-and-file morale is dismal.

pros: The University does offer a strong package of vacation and sick time. Some positions offer limited flexibility in work schedule.
cons: Systems and paperwork are overwhelmingly prevalent, and it's extremely difficult to find the "right" way to do things. Silo-ing is prevalent. There's a lot of uncertainty because of the State of Illinois' budget situation and an ongoing recategorizing of jobs. Many positions are Civil Service, which means they're subject to union representation. This can be good, but it also subjects people to the possibility of being laid off if a more senior person wants your position. I work in a unit with a really great group of people, but it appears, from dealing with other departments, that there are a lot of people who work here, but don't care about their job beyond not being fired. I would likely leave rather than be transferred to another unit in the University.

review_title: It is a very poorly run university.
pros: I worked with some very nice people, and it is easy to access the university by either the 'L' or buses.
cons: It is incredibly poorly run institution.  I would have appreciated it if they would have at least cleaned our restrooms once a month and restocked the bathrooms with toilet paper (no joke!) Instead, we would have to call maintenance multiple times to remind them that we were out of toilet paper, paper towels, etc. Meanwhile, the maintenance people would sit around texting and eating chips while the rest of us worked late.  The building I worked in was literally filthy.  Aside from the lack of cleanliness, there was no cohesiveness within the department where I worked.  I would not recommend it to other job applicants unless this was your only opportunity.

review_title: This is the epitome of a Chicago institution
pros: Performance expectations and metrics are low to non-existent.  No one works a full day.  No one EVER comes in on a weekend.  Bright and competent people will neither be recognized nor rewarded, but it is extremely easy to get paid well for doing nothing here (or your second job...) if that's your aim.  The ideal place for anyone who has given up on the American workplace as anything other than a sham that you can work to your favor.
cons: Chicago cronyism is the rule of the day. The University of Illinois system as a whole makes some of the all-time worst leadership hires on record and the place is in a constant state of flux/turmoil because of it.  The day-to-day of education goes on as it always does and people do as little as possible to keep the doors open and the lights on, but by-and-large the system is an astonishing waste of our tax dollars.

review_title: Current Building Manager at UIC - Student Services Building and have been employed here for 2 and a half years.
pros: Great for students looking for extra money for expenses. Not only is it one of the higher-paying jobs on campus but it is also a relatively laid back job.  A lot of downtime to work on homework or other things on your agenda.  Leanient on work hours and getting days off. Typically days are available to pick up, so you are able to pick up more hours if necessary.  Nice culture,  with a friendly diverse team of employers.
cons:
Morning shifts are typically worked at least once a week which start at 630am
Conference room Set-ups at night can be pretty big and take about an hour 
Front and center of building so you will have questions being asked a lot.

review_title: [SPECIFICALLY FOR ENGINEERING AT UIC] Too many toxic engineering faculty. Treated like dirt if you don't have a PhD.
pros: Generous vacation (depending on position), good benefits, can create a decent work-life balance. Plenty of opportunity to change positions and go to different parts of the university.
cons: Disorganized and poorly maintained. People frequently kept in the dark. Too many rotten apples in the barrel, but they are tenured, so nothing can be done. Many faculty in the engineering departments treat non-PhDs disrespectfully--like they are beneath them/servants for the department. Some departments are incredibly misogynistic and racist. Many employees have a pass the buck mentality because taking responsibility and ownership only leads to more work and criticism. Too many politics and petty faculty members can make the environment toxic and stressful.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant (Chemistry) in Manila, Manila
pros: Most of the adjunct professors are actually okay to teach for, and the office staff is great. The department head (Luke Hanely) is a pretty reasonable guy too.
cons: The undergraduate chemistry curriculum here is completely disorganized. The lab manual has errors in it that they never fix, and you will deviate from the instructions routinely because they changed every lab but never bothere to change the manual. The labs spaces are also horribly outdated and all the equipment is broken. And while most of the adjuncts are okay to work for, many of them are pretty bad at teaching, so you will be tortured every semester watching undergraduates struggle to teach the material to themselves until you become numb to it all.

pros:
As far as academic institutions, I enjoyed working at UIC. 
It was very family friendly - I had three children while working there, and the staff had extremely supportive. I believe I had 12 weeks of paid maternity leave (between sick leave and FMLA), and my vacation time was 4 weeks a year. They were also very understanding when I would need to leave early to pick up a sick child from daycare. I was never made to feel like my career was suffering because I chose to have a family AND a career, and for that I am very thankful to my directors and colleagues.
cons: UIC is very siloed, and very humble about their accomplishments. There's a lot of really interested and exciting research that happens at UIC, but it's never discussed outside of the department that it's happening in. Without promoting accomplishments, I feel like the University (and its students) often get overlooked.

review_title: Great potential -- but be mindful of your department's reputation
pros: Location, location, location.  Easy to get to, easy to get away from, and lots happening around the perimeter of the campus.  Good students in general for an urban university.  Workload not onerous either for faculty or admin.  Good benefits for permanent staff.  Decent pay.  Many departments around campus (e.g. public admin, math, medical, dentistry, architecture) are truly outstanding.
cons: Institution still afflicted with a sense of inadequacy and self-hatred.  Stanley Fish unfortunately didn't get the time he needed to work his magic because of Blago.  Damage done by ex-governor will take a long time to recover.  Goals as a consequence of the 2003-04 cutbacks on top of the earlier cuts have been set lower than they probably should.

pros: Opportunity to explore a wide variety of personal and professional interests because the workplace is within an academic atmosphere.  Also, the work/life balance is a real asset as well as the availability of free professional workshops/webinars and the ability to earn an advanced degree while working for the university.
cons: Easier to make lateral moves within the university rather than vertical moves to advance your career.  Also, a bit of a bureaucracy in terms of large volumes of paperwork required to get things done, which can be frustrating and can often feel like a waste of your time, but I'm sure there is a reason for it all.

job_title: IT Technical Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: The Technology was great, and so was the fact that I got to implement it as I saw fit. Getting to attend Budget Planning Meetings with Directors and decide the IT Budget was great. Purchasing equipment was great.
cons: Most of the people were nice, but 25% had dark hidden agendas, and went out of their way to make everything difficult for those trying to do things right. Even goung so far as to threaten people with dismissal if they would not undermine the efforts of others. I wish the system here would allow me to enter the correct dates for this job. I haven't worked since due to stress related medical issues. A nice job gone awry.

job_title: Athletic Communications/Sports Information in Chicago, IL
pros: Campus in great locale. Minutes from downtown and the West Loop neighborhood. Some very talented, loyal, hard-working people in the athletic department and on campus. Baseball, softball and soccer field have tremendous view of skyline, including the Willis Tower. Close to public transportation, and on-campus parking is available. Coaches were great to work with, and appreciative of communications' team's role.
cons: Limited resources, and high turnover. Good people have been fired for no apparent reason. Work-life balance can be very challenging due to small staff size. The campus neighborhood can be dangerous at night. There wasn't great synergy between the athletic department and campus.

review_title: This was the absolute worst job I've ever had and the most dysfunctional organization I've ever worked for.
pros: (1) Four weeks vacation during your first year; (2) generous amount of holidays, personal days, and sick time; (3) decent medical plan; and (4) a great amount of flexibility with your schedule
cons: Like most universities, UIC takes great pride in employing people on research teams who have attained a high level of education. Unfortunately, since the overwhelming majority of these people lack experience or training in business, they are pretty clueless when it come to figuring out how to effectively lead a project team, develop employees, and acknowledge and address conflict. Working under a principle investigator or project coordinator with no leadership or business skills can be extremely frustrating.

pros:
Great time off benefits
Excellent pretax deductions
Great health insurance: vision and dental as well
State Retirement system is matched up 6% after 5 years
cons:
No incentive to perform optimally 
No promotion or raise options
No annual increase beyond state approved 2%, but since state is in a deficit, no increase for the last 3 years. 
No self improvement funds
State retirement is not optional contribution. It's automatic 8% deduction which you cannot borrow from or withdraw while employed by the University.

review_title: A great but sometimes frustrating opportunity that gave me a chance to develop my personal skills and contribute.
pros: Working w/ student staff and forming a community with the students living on campus has been very rewarding. While receiving free housing was a nice benefit and the main reason why most students pursue becoming a resident assistant, it was the personal and professional relationships that I made that made it worthwhile.
cons: A very large disconnect between student staff and upper management. And a lack of communication between the inner departments of Campus housing (eg Resident Assistants and Desk workers). And very apparent lack of funding, resources and maintenance in the residence halls.

review_title: Great for Public Health Starting Point.
pros: The researchers are all very supportive of graduate assistants. They help teach you about their research and are a great resources as you develop your career. The Institute is a wonderful place to start as a researcher in public health and(or) occupational research.
cons: There really isn't much leadership presence throughout, or at least I didn't see it as a graduate assistant. The office culture is very quiet and there doesn't seem to be much cohesion. Each person has their own research and you don't interact so much with other people in the office outside of people who work with you for your project.

review_title: Not a bad experience if you work with an advisor who works on a state of the art research project.
pros: It's a small school near downtown Chicago. If you like to work in small groups under not so much pressure, it might suit you.
cons: Salaries are not enough for living in a mega city like Chicago. Small school/department, not so many great advisors in college of engineering (especially CME department). Most of the research projects are not state of the art. Some faculty members are not professional in their behavior showing no respect for grad students.

pros: Flexible schedule, good pay for part-time work, tuition stipend, GAO does a good job at negotiating salary increases on our behalf, Graduate students are the backbone of the university so you will absolutely feel as though you are contributing!
cons: It can be difficult to juggle full time graduate school, internships, and an assistantship (not to mention time for a social life and extra-circulars!). However, this is the best way to ensure that you're not riddled with debt upon leaving school- I recommend an assistantship to any who are lucky enough to get one!

job_title: IT Technical Associate in Chicago, IL
pros:
Employment at The University system still allows Unions to play and important role in its employment systems for their workers. 

Many employees can become employed under an existing state run labor system, such as the Civil Service, or University run Academic Professional system.
cons:
Limited transparency on information seeking future employment opportunities.  Difficult to acquire annual pay raises and learn of new employment opportunities in advance of posting. 

Many job positions require a college degree, or advanced degree regardless of skill needed to perform duties.
Job responsiblities sometimes not clearly defined and may overlap with other job classes.

job_title: Student Aide- Special Collections in Chicago, IL
pros: The only pros to this job are that it is a flexible schedule and that the other student workers are very friendly.
cons: The upper level employees in Special Collections treat the student employees terribly. They will complain about you for simply talking to another employee or if you are smiling and laughing. They are miserable people that have settled for the job and it really shows. The worst upper level employees at Special Collections have to be Peggy and Kellee. They will go to your manager and complain daily if they see you being happy.

pros: Good life/work balance. Good benefits, esp. the 20+ days of annual vacation and 8% retirement contribution rate. Education is a worthy cause.
cons: Because of the great benefits -and because it is hard to fire someone - it attracts a lot of complacent workers just phoning it in every day. Hard to work with faculty too because the academic culture is so at odds with the business culture (deadlines, quick decision making, etc.). A lot of bureaucracy. Everything is done by committee so this means decisions take forever to get made. Again, an example of the academic culture that is at odds with business needs.

pros: "Free" Housing, Close to campus, many networking opportunities
cons:
- Complete lack of transparency from those in management position. 
- Multiple large projects are assigned out of the blue with only a few days to work on any one project that would typically require weeks to complete properly. 
- Organization policy constantly changing
- Policy enforcement being inconsistent and holding a high level of favoritism. 
- Completely obstinate to feedback on ways to improve to the point that co-workers were threatened with termination for voicing concerns. 
- Very low morale among employees
- The expectation to be autonomous unit but perform specific tasks in a certain manner without instruction or proper training.

review_title: Amazing place to work as a CS undergraduate researcher
job_title: Computer Specialist II in Chicago, IL
pros:
The lab was very relaxing and the management was never breathing down your neck.
Access to technology that people think only exists in movies
Great group of people to be working around and learn from
cons:
Sometimes classes using the lab would be in the way so scheduling was a must.
Until you've been around for a bit sometimes you can feel like an outsider to those working there.

review_title: My experience at the University of Illinois at Chicago wasn't either great nor bad it was a students job.
pros: Its a good place to work because it allows you to interact with all types of people. If you are capable it allows you to move up to a manger.
cons: There is no basic pay raise like in most jobs. The only way for a promotion is to become a student manger. I feel like there should be more opportunities. Managemtn needs to understand that their employees no more than what they think they know.

review_title: Medical School campus culture and staff are unimpressive.  The bar is low
job_title: Manager of Research Operations in Chicago, IL
pros: 5 weeks vacation per year,  free graduate education is phenomenal and a great perk. Benefits outweigh the negative side of working at UIC without a doubt.  For this reason alone I recommend it as a place ti work.
cons: The administrative staff is rife with nepotism.  The commute to this campus is arduous.  Management is overpaid.  They get huge salaries and no sooner they arrive they leave to greener pastures.  They use UIC as a stepping stone or as a way to feather their retirement nest.

review_title: People are nice but the system is slow.
pros: Chicago is a great city and univ. is right next to downtown. There are some really cool project in every dept. The health care is very good. The electronic systems are getting better slowly but smoothly. The Rec. center is great and fairly good equipted. There are kind of great pulic transportation.
cons: There is a common negetive envierment amoung the faculty,staff, and even graduate students. The dept. expect a lot. The tution diferential of this univ is higher than most of univ. but the pay is lower than the rest. There are a lot of fees and the parkings are expensive.

review_title: Okay, but other fees could be lower
pros: If you are a PhD student, your work is mostly on your research topic, not much work is needed on other topics. If you are not a PhD student, but working for experience, it is worth it.
cons: If you are also a student at UIC, you have to pay around $1000 per semester for various fees and health insurance. Very often, the PI's are laid back, and you need to take the initiative to work. And there is significant bureaucracy which takes many problems forever to solve.

review_title: UIC was not the place for me.
job_title: Office Administrative Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Working independently. Union job - 5 weeks vacation, 2 weeks sick time, 8-10 holidays, 7.5 hour workday.
cons: Impossible to get to unless you drive or live in city near Pink Line. The UIC bus to the hospital from the Metra takes additional 30 minutes. One Year probation for union. Typically fire people 10 months in for lame reasons.

review_title: Nepotistic, unfriendly, dirty politics, unprofessional atmosphere.
pros: Close to downtown, few really good people who suffer silently, long 10 day Christmas break.
cons: For almost all jobs, there is a candidate who is the hiring manager wants in the position, yet the ad is put out to fulfill requirements of equal opportunity. Some people do nothing and still get paid because their supervisors want them in the position and don't care. It's such a waste of tax payers dollars. No wonder the state sales and income tax rates are the highest in the nation. Simple things are made complicated and there is such an unnecessary waste of resources.

pros: Flexibility. Benefits package (PTO is abundant), which balances out the low pay.  And the population served.
cons: No accountability. Change organization with no steady infrastructure. Disorganized. Poor management.

pros: Great flexibility in hours. They allow students to choose whatever hours works best for their schedules because they understand we are in school. They try to give us any design help and technology help they can.
cons: Your pay does not meet Chicago's minimum wage of $10/hr because it is a state school. The longer you work here, the more opportunities you get for a raise, but you have to ask for the raises and be aware of them.

review_title: Got to learn a lot both in terms of technical and general management
pros:
Good working environment -- work life balance 
Good funding for research since it is a public university . Funding promotes innovation!!
Very talented professors
cons:
Purely academic setting does not give any flavor of how it is like working in a private company
More focused on research -- good for those who want continue their careers in research in academics but not great for those who want to make a transition to industry

job_title: Visiting Project Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Outstanding benefits, good pay, friendly work culture.  Opportunities to take courses for free or at reduced tuition. Overall, the administrative, clerical and support teams are very helpful and work as teams. Motivation to keep going is built in every time you meet a student on campus or a patient at the hospital, because your reason to serve is always visible.
cons: Funding is always an issue, and fear of budget cuts is palpable on campus.

job_title: Building Service Worker in Chicago, IL
pros: I'm still working full time during the pandemic.
cons: I was working at the UIC campus. I was informed that the UIC Hospital was shorthanded on building service workers. So myself & 4 co-workers from the UIC campus were temporarily re-assigned until we are notified. All 5 of us are now front line hospital workers, a spot we didn't sign up for.

pros: Work really well with student schedules, so you don't have to worry about changing your schedule for the job if you are a full-time student. Nice Convent location, depending on what department you are place, the job does not require too much work.
cons: A con would be that they do not pay the minimum wage. Sometimes the part-time workers are seen as easily replaceable and most departments have a very high turnover rate.

review_title: Interesting work, but high potential for exploitation
pros:
Most faculty members are friendly and engaging
Some administrators are helpful and knowledgeable
Flexible schedules and very good benefits
There are opportunities to expand your skills and take initiative
cons: Many employees (faculty and staff) are burnt-out, the culture on campus is very negative.  There is an ongoing feud between UIC and UIUC which makes collaboration across campuses difficult.  UIC does not appear to have a clear vision for the future, so it's hard to get excited about growth.

pros:
Schedule flexibility was good as a student.  I was able to work part-time in a '9 to 5' office during the day and part time at the campus information desk after hours and on weekends.
I would suggest working in the Student Services Building as it gives you access to many different offices and thus, more job options.  Look into campus housing; I think some resident assistants get reduced room and/or board.
cons:
I wish I had pursued career at the university after graduating instead of private corporate America.
After graduation, the Civil Service application and process seem time-consuming, especially when employed full-time elsewhere.

review_title: Good place, low pay and appreciation
pros: The University is centrally located and easily accessible by way of public transportation. The students  environment and culture here is wonderful and the students are great people.  Flexible hours and GREAT vacation and sick leave benefits.
cons: The upper administration at UIC seriously devalues the administrative staff; it is extremely difficult to get promoted and/or obtain a salary increase. Employees are rarely acknowledge for the commitment to the university, thus causing the morale to be lower than it should.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros:
Very open, accepting, and community-centered institution
Mission statement emphasizes service to diverse urban community
Lots of room for growth and opportunities to take the lead on things
cons:
As a public university, the institution is at the whim of the state's budget woes (i.e. lack of one)
Relatively young research university still figuring out who and what it wants to be

review_title: Great institution with enormous potential but weak leadership missing opportunities.
pros:
Great research
Important mission to care for the underprivileged.
Very diverse student body and international faculty.
Chicago is a great city to live.
cons: Poor leadership with frequently changing senior leaders fighting each other. No agreement between various deans, chancellor, provost with open fights. Medical and non-medical part of campus in disagreement. Little dialogue among faculty.

pros: Very fun and driven professional staff that make sure every day at work  is exciting and enjoyable. As a student this position could not have been a better way to make money while going to school. Employee input is taken seriously and changes are actively made to ensure employees have to best possible environment to work in possible.
cons: Professional staff tends to change fairly frequently so you could end up having a new manager multiple times throughout your employment.

review_title: An excellent employer if you can get in.
pros: The hiring process is very thorough (background checks, references, etc).  It's all done online initially, but once hired, you show up to HR where you will read and fill quite a few forms, many are ethical in nature (won't discriminate, hurt, steal, etc) .  While it is extremely difficult to get any job at UIC because of the current hiring freeze (which really isn't a freeze...it's more of a slow down), you can either go the civil route (need to take exam) or academic route.  Many jobs are not advertised and there is a way to get a temporary 6 month assignment through the academic route where departments fill short-comings in their staffs.  They do advertise the official civil and academic jobs, but in my opinion, these are very hard to get because so many people apply for the small amount of jobs listed.  The temporary academic jobs can lead to a full time job if they decide to formally create the position which has to be approved by HR.   Once hired, the process takes a while for HR to get you "official."  It took about one month since being hired to start.  While HR is very nice, they are by the book and will not help you in any way to give advice.  I think this is because of past cronyism  that has been cleaned up and they probably are trained not to help to avoid any perceived preference to candidates.  Once in the system, the benefits are pretty standard but as an employee, classes are free and you can earn your degree as long as you get accepted in the program of course.  The campus is safe where I work (by the medical campus).  There are police everywhere, emergency telephone beacons every block, and the hospital campus is pretty safe.  The Polk street L station is close by and UIC and CTA buses are everywhere.  Taylor street is awesome.  A lot of great pubs, restaurants, etc.  You also can get breaks at the new beautiful fitness center, CTA passes, and even a discount on your Sprint cell phone bill ($35 off my family plan!), and very cheap software for your personal use like Windows, Office for Mac (only $90!), Adobe Suites, etc. There are also many groups, organizations, associations, lectures, etc that are open to many so you can easily get involved if you have the desire.  The students are very down to Earth and I have not encountered attitudes like the "I am God complex" that are typical of DePaul, Loyola, Northwestern and University of Chicago students.  The students are culturally diverse and so are the staffs which is so refreshing.
cons: HR is currently re-classifying all academic jobs and they are converting them to civil jobs to prevent the academic departments from hiring people they know, but in my opinion, HR just ends up hiring some unqualified people because they seem to go out of their way to hire people without graduate degrees from what I have been noticing, thus opening jobs to a greater proportion of the population that don't supposedly get a fair shake at jobs traditionally held by people with graduate degrees, but the quality of hires goes down. I don't think a graduate degree is the ultimate qualification for every job, but that should not be counted against you when applying.  I think they need to re-think their hiring process.   Also, many academics run the departments you work in and they don't tell you about all the benefits like tuition reimbursements, etc.

review_title: Working at UIC College of Dentistry
job_title: Staff Nurse II and Clinical Management in Chicago, IL
pros:
Excellent salary and benefits
Day shift, no weekends or holidays
Civil Service and union status
cons:
Lack of leadership and direction
Difficult to implement positive changes
Resistance to improvements/changes
Lack of mentoring of employees
Lack of encouragement to attend training or further career
Small pay raises
Employees not monitored for work performance, lack of performance reviews

review_title: A great opportunity to earn some money and a tuition waiver.
pros:
- Monthly Stipend
- Tuition waiver
- Ineresting work
- Publication opportunities
- Interdepartmental collaborations
- Great system of alumni and collaborators to network with when heading out into industry
cons:
- May have to work beyond your paid 20 hrs
- Have to research what is being funded
- Older buildings have poor heating and cooling, resulting in annoyingly warm or cold temperatures for months at a time.

review_title: Poor pay and riddled with Bureaucracy
job_title: Visiting Research Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: My specific grant funded job was great and I had a great boss. My specific unit and my colleagues were amazing and became good friends but working with the actual university was always difficult.
cons: The University and its systems drove me mad with their inefficiency and disregard of employees. They pay very poorly and the non tenured professors recently went on strike due to the absurdly low pay.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: Nice facilities for structural biochemists - NMR spectrometers, ITC and DSC calorimeters, CD, fluorescence and UV/Vis spectrometers. Good colleagues, pretty good lab spaces, and overall nice city
cons: It is a big state school - the budget is cut every year or so, no new hires in years in my department, so we don't have any untenured tenure-track faculty. No real possibility for postdocs/research track faculty to upgrade

job_title: Service Desk Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: It is a great place to work and has great benefits. For example employees have access to a tuition waiver to attend classes. Understanding institution to work for depending on what unit you are employed with.
cons: With the Illinois state budget in chaos sometimes it is a bit unnerving being employed by a  state institution. Also, there is not a lot of room for growth.

review_title: Great work Environment - Lower Avg Pay
pros: The University is great. It has most of the facilities one needs to conduct decent research. The Professors are nice and encouraging. A lot of amenities including a CCTS program helps people who want to pursue translational science. A detailed Responsible conduct of research program conducted by Prof Gemeinhart is very useful for any beginners.
cons: The average pay for a Postdoc fellow in the Chicago area is close to 45K. However most Profs pay you under that value. Chances of procuding funding are dependent on how hard you work.

review_title: Student Jobs are the best if you only need pocket money to get by!!
pros: It is an on-campus job so they work with your schedule. Especially since when students are at the mercy of class scheduling. Its nice to get to go to work when you can!
cons: Office politics! Get used to them. Learn how to navigate through them. Learn to be Switzerland as a student worker.

review_title: Keep all of your options open
pros:
laid back environment
incompetent and still has a job
tuition waivers
lots of vacation and sick days
independent
cons:
low salaries, always keep an open eye for a better position
dumb and incompetent bosses, their salary might be high enough, that they will stay there until they die
if you know how to do something, you'll be doing all the work
lots of work and no directions
no training, no information

review_title: Opportunities for professional and career growth with the reduction of unnecessary red-tape.
pros: UIC offers good work and life balance, as well as stable job outlook. The company has all the resources one could want for in order to improve and increase services and performances.
cons: The flip-side is that there are a lot of duplicated resources that create undue gateways and extra paths to get things done.

review_title: Good place for students pursuing a graduate degree
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Depending on the department you can have flexible hours and work from home. This helps you organize your work schedule in a way that doesn't interfere with classes. If you are lucky to work in an project of your interest you can learn a lot.
cons: You don't get to interact with many people. If you like to work in groups this is not the type of job for you. You have to be very organize in order to have work-life balance. Sometimes work can be overwhelming.

review_title: Good place to work for students who are pursuing a graduate discipline.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Flexible hours, part time employment. Some jobs allow you to work from home making it easier to fit in your class schedule. Also good for international students who can only work 20 hours a week while going to school full time.
cons: Old School work culture that sometimes makes it a little mundane. Also, the pay is not very competitive. Employees can earn more working part time elsewhere.

pros: It is one of the best places to work with as they fund your education and also are very flexible with students. one of the best places to learn and succeed
cons: nothing really comes to mind as a stand out negative factor . i would any day advice uic to any students as it is the best place to be in

review_title: It was a pleasant experience although the management sucks and they don't make professional decisions.
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The benefits are the pros for this employer, they have good retirement benefits that can be good for you if you have children.
cons: The drama and lack of professionalism. The management for some offices are very unprofessional and lack common sense of managing a company.

review_title: A headache that could be worth it if you're very lucky
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: At least you can find yourself around -- a diverse set of -- people who are doing interesting work or are passionate about their field of expertise.
cons: Employees / graduate students are basically disposable labor, and the laboratory support staff are often treated poorly and undercompensated as well. Depending on where you work it can be a bureaucratic, messy, and precarious nightmare that your better off avoiding in the first place, especially so for TAs and RAs that are international students.

review_title: Decent job security but low growth.
pros: -Excellent benefits package even for entry level employees.  All employees receive 25 paid time off and almost just as many sick days.
cons: -Growth and salary raises are very hard to obtain.  Very difficult to find a higher level position and justified pay even with experience.  Your salary is capped out quickly.

review_title: Its a great place to work.
pros: The University of Illinois at Chicago has a lot of GA's. I loved my experience here was fabulous. please come and work here.
cons: They seem to be closing down some graduate assistant  positions. I dont know why they are doing it. Otherwise its a great place to work. Please try it!!

pros:
Good way to start your career 
Work and life balance
cons:
People work in silos
Very hierarchy organization from the classification of civil service employees to academic professional employees ( AP) which is not the same from department/college to college.  If you are classified as a civil service people will treat you without respect.
Compensation and classification is not the same from department to department or college to college. You might be doing the same job as someone else or even more  and be making less in salary.

pros:
Many resources, tuition paid for employees, great mentors within specialty areas of nursing!
Ability to be autonomous.
Great reputation in the nursing community-worldwide!
Many opportunities to get involved in research, volunteering, or the local community!
Very well-prepared faculty-committed to students!
cons:
Many faculty-sometimes overwhelming.
Have to be assertive to get your needs heard/met.
Poor salary. Much below the national average for faculty.
A better orientation would be helpful, especially for new faculty.
Poorly organized clinical placement procedure-students & faculty don't know where they will be going until the last minute!

pros:
Received many valuable lessons and experiences as a research aide. The hands on projects and responsibilities really gave me the experience and tools i needed to get into the workforce confidently. 

P.S. This was my first job out of college, and while it was temporary, I would recommend everybody go through their college employment office to gain valuable "real life" work experince.
cons: Going through a schools hiring system can be tedious and frustrating, but once its done it gets better.

job_title: College of Engineering Tutor in Chicago, IL
pros: Awesome I think that the school has made great strides and I can personally attest to the fact that my life has improved drastically in the process.
cons: Mehh, I dont really know if this is the school for most. The party life is pretty dull and there is a lot of crime in the area. Steer clear of this dumpy school

review_title: Excellent place to work while going to school
pros: Very easy about working around my school schedule and understanding if I needed extra time off to study.  Coworkers were all very friendly and laid back, not a very stressful place to work.
cons: You're not getting paid a whole lot, but it was nice to have a little money in my pocket while going to school

pros: I had a great team and enjoyed working with like-minded people. I had the flexibility to work on projects that interested me and which I really enjoyed. My supervisor was genuinely interested in the work and did not micromanage.
cons: Slow pace; it was difficult to get things done due to bureaucracy and politics between university departments. Our office was constantly being shuffled around between buildings, so that sometimes coworkers' offices were no where near the rest of the staff within large buildings.

review_title: Great benefits but lack of clear management and structure
pros: Benefits are great.  Interesting work.  Compared to private industry, there is more job security here (although state funding cuts do create less certainty).
cons: Offices are structured as independent entities, which causes competition within the university instead of collaboration.  There is no clear path toward promotion.

review_title: State's Financial Issues impact job growth
pros: Great people to work with and job security
cons: No raises in close to 5 years.  One year we were furloughed and had to give some money back to our employer!  In my particular college, there was no employee recognition.

pros: Great atmosphere;  overall really enjoyed the people I worked with.  The students I worked with were also really nice.  Overall ok work for students during the semester.
cons: Pay was not desirable.; less than the minimum wage of Chicago.  Communication between the tutors and management was almost non existent.

review_title: This school takes great pride in not advancing diversity among faculty in the sciences and hiring unqualified spouses.
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: close to public transportation and sufficient library resources.
cons: Do not come here if you are a minority scientist who is non-Asian.  Their School of Public Health has never hired an African American tenured track professor in its 40+ year history in their Environmental Health Sciences Division.  Most schools try to hire faculty from across the country however this school tends to hire its own graduates and perpetuates its dysfunctional and discriminatory staff.

review_title: Quite a good choice for a decent start
job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Peoria, IL
pros: Small project groups working on cancer, Alzheimer's, etc. Quite work place, with ample scope to overlap in multiple projects. Especially good when one has a career change in mind to core cellular and molecular biology techniques and biomedical sciences research.
cons: Pretty isolated location. Very limited opportunities in bio-related jobs in the neighborhood. Also, employee tuition benefits though applicable, but might be hard to avail as not many courses would be available in that small setup.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: If you work in a good lab with a good advisor on top notch projects, and have made good connections in industry along the way, you might land a decent job after your graduation.
cons: The above mentioned Pros may rarely be met in most engineering departments.

review_title: Leadership needs work, benefits can be good
pros: Paid time off and sick leave are both very generous.  Insurance coverage can be excellent.  Academic employees tend to have fairly flexible schedules.
cons: You pay dearly for have Ign excellent health insurance coverage.  Deans and department heads tend to be academics with little skill and no interest in running third college/department.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Very friendly environment and very collegial atmosphere overall, no qualms about the nature of work. But it depends from lab to lab, office to office. The west campus is pretty chilled out, despite of cutting edge research.
cons: Work-life balance is poor. Also, the pay provided is minimal and the wages could be higher compared to some competitive labs in the same area.

pros: Both east-side and west-side have similar facilities. I lived all my five years on west-side campus but like the east-side though. UIC has excellent commute reachability.
cons: West-side reports some shady areas and report 'crime alerts'. Sometimes it gets difficult to identify where does UIC shares its land with Rush and Cook County Hospital.

review_title: Flexible and understanding, one of the best place for students to work
job_title: Campus Housing Operation Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: allows you to take time off if you have exams coming up, managements are very nice and reasonable.  workload is average.  co-workers are super friendly.
cons: supervisor is not helpfull, and does not allow employees to help some of the ESL workers.  Saying something like "these group of people reports to me, not you.  they come to me if they have questions"

review_title: Excellent benefits and high quality work environment tempered by limited opportunities
job_title: Visiting Project Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: UIC is an impressive organization that offers its employees great benefits and opportunities for personal advancement, particularly through tuition waivers for graduate and certificate education.
cons: Non-faculty professionals are treated as largely expendable, with too many positions classified as "visiting."

pros: Nice people to work for. Good facilities in the Institute for Juvenile Research where I worked.   Pay was decent.
cons: HR was often very very slow to get things processed.  A lot of things had to go down to UIUC, which means getting simple things approved took unnecessarily long.  HR tended to treat you like they were doing you a favor when really they were just doing their jobs.

pros: People are nice and friendly, generous and willing to help; The facility is spacious and the location is close to downtown and convenient to get access to CTA trains/buses.
cons: There is food court in the building, you have to go out to buy lunch. And to get access to a nice restaurant will cost 15-min walk.

pros: You can work whenever you want on projects. The problem is that the professor may or may not be competent enough to actually land you a job afterwards.
cons: I have no idea how you would get hired from this place after being a "Research Assistant" but you better get an offer letter from a company before you graduate because no one else will help you.

review_title: A great environment to work in
pros: Everyone there work hard and are willing to assist others when needed. There is always something to be done, and it is always done in a timely matter.
cons: Sometimes events can be a little hectic, but everything turns out to be alright. There are really no Cons to working at this establishment.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: As a PhD candidate in UIC, the part-time RA job is the best because basically you just work in the lab doing your thesis research without any extra work. And your supervisor pays you. Plus we have good benefit. Our insurance and all general fees are paid by our supervisor as well. This is only for PhD students in College of Medicine.
cons: Stipend is still lower than other university in Chicago area like Northwestern and U of Chicago.

review_title: There is a lack of focus and drive, as well as a lack of funding.
pros: Generally amicable advisers and coworkers, work load is light, hours are flexible, and 26 days paid vacation. Many publications should be possible.
cons: This is not a top tier university, and it shows. There is a general lack of funding all around, and equipment is not the best, but not terrible either.

review_title: Community of Teachers, Researchers, and Civically Engaged Learners
job_title: Teacher and Researcher in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent intellectual culture; diverse campus; Chicago's largest public research university; community engagement; centrally located in the heart of Chicago; community of socially and politically engaged learners.
cons: Teaching assistant stipends can be difficult in meeting the cost of living in Chicago. Healthcare and dental benefits can be difficult to utilize without guidance.

pros: Studies allow interviewers to have a very flexible schedule. Good job for students. Not many positions available for in office work.
cons: Not a lot of room for opportunity. Mainly only part time positions are offered through the the Survey Research Lab. Studies mainly require interviewers to work evenings and weekends.

pros: university of illinois at chicago is near downtown Chicago, a nice city in US. so it is very convenient to enjoy the big city life style.
cons: The ranking is so so. after you get a degree, it is not so easy to find a good job in the well-known big companies

pros: It is a stable job, great benefits, lots of time off.  Co-workers are friendly and there is a lot to learn there.
cons: Being a gov't run place, it takes a lot of time to get things done.  Also, the smaller departments do not get any recognition nor is thier advice taken seriously.

review_title: Project Coordinator at University of Illinois Chicago
pros: Good benefits package.  Lots of vacation and personal days.  Convenient to the train.  A lot of departments and job opportunities for transferring.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy.  The environment in certain departments is very cold.  Areas around campus can be dangerous.

pros: good compensation which will help you in paying your differential fee. a major chunk of your tuition is waived. take time off when necessary.
cons: repetitive work. work is not extremely challenging. critical administrative decisions are made towards the death when there is no way out of the problem

review_title: Graduate School at the Pharmacy College - Teaching / Research Assistant
pros: Good people, classes are small (for the graduate students), diverse group of educators, many PI choices.
cons: If you are not a self-starter then you may feel a little lost - not necessarily a con for me.

review_title: Easy work, but no one here cares
pros: easy work, no time-clocks, relaxed atmosphere, not many challenges.
cons: the management doesn't care.  being a research based institution, there doesn't seem to be a sense of urgency with anything around here.   You also can't really challenge yourself here (a Pro for some).

pros: If you are looking to make an impact, UIC serves an amazingly diverse demographic, with a high percentage of first generation college students.
cons: You are working for the State of Illinois. The state is politically and financially broken. Service will ultimately diminish if Rauner and Madigan continue to not play nice.

pros: After working here for 10 years, it is clear that this university is a microcosm of Chicago and the higher ed sector.  Overall, I would recommend because there are opps for growth, many learning opps and creative, interesting people.
cons: With the opps for learning, most systems are university-specific.  Not sure how universal and transferable systems are to other universities.  That said, stretching and learning can paradoxically help you always.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The research experience is very good and the exposure towards academia is unparalleled.
cons: Very long working hours. Being a smaller university which focuses more on graduate programs the pressure to produce results is very high. Some of the professors are focused on micro-management which leaves less room for independent work.

review_title: A very unique institution that is rapidly becoming a global player in higher education.
pros: Diverse and young with a bright and growing future. Many opportunities to grow professionally with so many new initiatives going on.
cons: Departmental solos with a very politically charged hierarchy. Advancement often means leaving your department to go elsewhere. Salary for one job can be vastly different for the same job elsewhere on campus.

review_title: Administration is proliferating at the expense of students and faculty
pros: Student diversity, location in a major city
cons: Administrative decisions lack transparency and often seem personality based; faculty union is  systematically undermined; no salary raises for faculty in the last years but administrators enjoy lavish compensation. The lack of equity is creating a class system

pros: Very flexible work schedule with supportive staff. There are weekly meetings and you get to listen to a lot of great music. Much of the music that you receive is sent directly from large promotion groups and record labels, so you do get direct music industry experience.
cons: There is not much training for the position and can often be too flexible. Because it is a student position, you work at minimum wage.

job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Offered some nice benefits with a PPO that had a maximum out of pocket medical expenses of $900 per year. However, that changed this year; the max is not $6,000. The rationale given is that more is covered. However, I would prefer a choice to keep the max per year lower.
cons: Much of the benefits is determined via their website. While helpful, there is a limited number of staff members to respond to questions.

review_title: General Office Aide, Federal work study position
job_title: General Office Aide in Chicago, IL
pros: Very simple job, you know exactly what you are meant to do, the bosses and co-workers make the job better. The pay is good for the amount of work you put into it.
cons: The possibility of running out of federal work study is there,  if you run out, you may be fired. This cuts down on the hours you are given, but this may not bother you.

review_title: UIC is a good University of doing research
pros: UIC has very solid and passionate Professors. The courses are easy. The teaching assistants are helpful. The gym at UIC is great. The study load at UIC is easy.
cons: The courses are too old and can not pick up the changing trends.The workload of PhD students are very heavy and thus doctorate students' work/Life balance is poor.  The environment, such as Lab equipments are old.

job_title: Student Worker In Student Affairs in Chicago, IL
pros: The amount of contacts you get in any field is extremely helpful for moving on when you you want too. People are generally friendly and you can learn a lot from group settings.
cons: There can be some weird bureaucracy here sometimes, decisions are made the higher ups and we're left to decipher it and work around it.

review_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant, Labs and Discussions Instructor, Tutor
pros: Diverse community, public school, Union for the Grad student employees, benefits: gym, healthcare, vision and dental plan, CTA pass
cons: Low salary for the TA's, incompetencies and bureaucracy in all departments, especially, the Office of International Affairs

pros: Flexible hours. Pay arrives on time. Friendly environment. People help each other out. Very diverse working group which helps in growth.
cons: Not much growth opportunity. Requires a lot of patience. It is a long term investment. And perks are not much. One can't go much higher in job position and salary.

review_title: University of Illinois College of Medicine
pros: Urban environment with a diverse student body & a commitment fighting against  health disparities in the Chicago region.
cons: It continues to suffer from decreased state support to its budget. State contributions are down to ~7% of the total operating costs, so it is forced to act like a private institution while still under state control.

pros: Strong professional environment, expectation of excellence, compassionate management when personal crises arise; great tech support, expectation of collaboration
cons: Unpredictability of contract hours; schedules often include weeknights and weekends as well as weekday mornings

job_title: Systems Administrator (Graduate Research Assistant) in Chicago, IL
pros: A great collegial atmosphere and camaraderie throughout the faculty and the staff in the department is encouraged by the Head. The staff through the years that I have worked there -- 2008 to 2011 -- have been amazing. My immediate supervisor in one of the best persons I have ever met.
cons: Not much career growth if you are seeking to enter systems administration full-time.

pros: Good to work as an student worker while in school. No interview required.
cons: From my own experience, the pay was low and just about the minimum wage. My professor was very inconsistent about the working time, they told me to come in according to everyone else's available time.

pros: Great teaching experience for aspiring academics. Opportunity to collaborate with interesting and like-minded people. The hours are flexible.
cons: The pay isn't great but not unreasonable considering the amount of hours worked. Grading papers can be mind-numbingly tedious. Some professors are less respectful than others about their grad students' time.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros:
- Good research university, some departments are very collaborative, which helps with networking if you plan to stay in academia
- Chicago is close to a lot of firms, allowing you to have an easy access to internships
cons:
- Very low salary for the cost of living in Chicago
- Depending on the PI, you will barely get any vacations

review_title: University of Illinois at Chicago, School of Pharmacy
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: Great place to do research, treats you really well, make sure you have all the resources to carry out your studies.
cons: Salary rate increase is low, ordering is sometimes difficult to arrange for necessary agents to arrive in a timely manner.

pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, union
cons:
If you like being barked at in Tagalog all day, spend half your shift charting rather than at the bedside, and provide nursing care without any idea why you're doing it, this is the place for you; I've never been so miserable at a nursing job as I was at UIC hospital. Management is inexperienced and inept. If you bring an issue to them, they just shrug and say something out of a 'Management for Dummies' book. Ancillary staff has zero accountability; on an average shift I had to call the kitchen at least 3 times for missing trays and they still didn't show up; If a patient needs a scan? 
 They'll get to it around 3am without warning. Unit clerks wearing headphones and eating chicken while working at the desk, swearing in front of patients, shouting down the hall; I've never seen so many hospital acquired pressure ulcers and falls! The hospital is falling apart so badly I was embarrassed to admit patients; 90% nursing staff speaks Tagalog throughout the shift in front of patients, alienating everyone else; nursing staff has no autonomy and are expected to just do what they're told (and they're fine with it); the residents are unprepared for their responsibilities; patients are undermedicated for pain,  stay in bed all day, and have extended stays.  Hospital has the highest rate of VTEs in the country. What should be a 3 day stay turns into 2 weeks. Not only would I not work here, I wouldn't get my healthcare here either.  Just stay away from this place!

pros: Very flexible in terms of scheduling when you can work. They do know that being a student comes first which is great especially when it's midterm or finals week.
cons: Some of the professional staff on the Campus Housing side are indecisive. At times, you would have to ask the same question worded differently each time for the staff member to understand what you're trying to say.

review_title: Great place to learn and share knowledge
pros:
Educational institute gives the opportunity to work with some of the brightest minds.
Flexible schedules
Chicago is a great place to live and work
cons:
Processes are not up to the industry standard.
The IT systems are not integrated and there is redundancy hence scope for improvement

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent benefits including substantial paid vacation days and paid sick days. Good health and dental benefits.
cons:
Completely disorganized at every single level of management. Lazy and incompetent employees. No consequences for inability to perform basic responsibilities. No consequences even for people who fail to arrive to work altogether, repeatedly, over the course of years, without reason. These are the people you will have to deal with, and pick up the slack for, if you are employed here. The University carries a lot of dead weight on a lot of different and costly levels. 

Every task is a process that requires many months time in order to complete. For example: Every single person in one department, upon receiving and accepting an offer for a position from the university, and after reporting to the job full-time, did not get PAID for 3+ months (in one case - for 6 MONTHS!) - only god knows why. "Processing" HR would say. Lots of phone calls to lots of different people who would each tell you something entirely different and refer you to someone else who was equally ill-equipped to answer basic questions they were required to know the answers to, as part of their job. After having not been paid for my first month of employment, I was told that period was considered "Volunteer" work, after which I would begin to be paid. Lies. They exploit employees, period. 

Additionally, employees were literally let go at the end of their contracts without any notice, and without any knowledge that they were let go at all. Four words: Milton from Office Space. People would continue to report to their jobs as usual, as they have been for 3+ years, because no one in management or HR told them: "Oh, by the way, we have not renewed your employment contract with UIC, and you no longer work here." (Typically, they were automatically renewed from year to year without discussion, simply, "Sign this.") Employees in "Visiting" positions whose contracts were not renewed at the end of their term only learned they no longer had a job - an entire month after they lost their jobs - because they did not see a paycheck automatically deposited into their bank accounts. Management allowed employees to continue to believe they were employed, and to continue to work, despite funding having run out for their positions and thus not paying them anymore. Even more unbelievable, this didn't occur in a single instance - this was department-wide (for  employees with an academic departmental position). 

More minor issues, comparatively: No raises. After several years of employment, it became costly to remain in this job, due to rising cost of living, and the stagnation of pay. Raises simply did not exist, and you can't get a straight answer from anyone as to why this is. You can't get a straight answer from anyone about anything, in general. Management will lie, or deflect, or cite ignorance, etc. 

No room for growth: In this particular position - you cannot go anywhere beyond "Research Coordinator." This is typical of this position in academia, however.  Unless you are pursuing a PhD in the field, which you can then perform your own research under. A Clinical Research Position in the corporate environment would progress into greater possibilities. 

Higher ups are often less knowledgeable than their research assistants. They don't know their own protocols. Their in-house practices do not match the contracts they agreed upon with funding institutions. They disregard eligibility criteria in favor of getting as many participants  in a study as possible. They simply don't know how to conduct (their own!) research. They have no clue what is required day-to-day in order for their studies to run smoothly. They don't know how to analyze data. They don't know where their laboratory equipment is located or how to use it. There is no guidance or support for RAs. RAs are expected to train themselves in areas of work the PI cannot and does no perform. And then, when there is an issue, the RAs are immediately to blame.. The issues go on, and on, and on... 

The list of grievances is miles long. Stay away from this University. Appointed officials are corrupt. Management is completely lost. Many employees are incompetent and simply do not perform work. There is no support. There is no accountability. There is no transparency.

review_title: Useful as an introduction to research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Tuition waiver and decent salary with the possibility of publishing research papers and add then to your research experience. Can be very fun if you're working on the topics you like.
cons: It all depends on team and projects, that many times vary widely. Projects can turn out to be less interesting than expected while team members (if any) can provide very little support.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Chicago, IL
pros: IHRP has a great network of researchers to work with. There are also a couple of competitive fellowships available for PhD students.
cons: The budget of the Univesrity is a mess. The administration is not always easy to navigate; it can get very political.

pros: Gain experiences in application and worked with many experts from different fields and wrote papers together.
cons: It was not so easy to find an RA on campus. Particularly, some RA positions were only known for certain faculties. Furthermore, most of the RA job are just an hourly job.

pros: Benefits of working for a state university are there including discounted tuition for staff and children, insurance, retirement, long-term disability, etc.
cons: A lot of the departments are underfunded and some are losing funding. Salary isn't the best and there seems to be issues with TA employee status/stipends across the board.

pros: academic research environment, good professors, and a lot of great students, a good place to start your careers, and also sponsor the H1
cons: the salary is not too high and the building is old, but people is friendly and nice. some departments are poor

pros: Great research institution with robust health sciences colleges amongst its 17 colleges. Great faculty and staff; smart, hard working students. Fantastic location just west of the loop.
cons: Hidden secret amongst competing higher ed institutions.

review_title: Great Pay, not so great infrastructure
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The pay is good. I work for 10 hours only per week and this job covers my tution fees which is $16000 per semester.
cons: Not very good infrastructure. A lot of software have older versions in use which are sometimes not even compatible with the latest operating systems.

review_title: It was great, not now; not rewarding Faculty who get grants but happy to take your ICR
pros: Flexible schedule, has the makings of a great research university that can move upward with proper investment in Faculty research. Teaching schedule is a a little lighter (compared to other 4-yr colleges) for Faculty in order to permit time for undergrad/graduate and post-grad research. We serve the student body by having flexible admission process and support for students in difficulties. We are diverse in culture and diverse learners--I was very proud to be teaching UIC students. Our students are/were the Greatest thing about UIC.
cons: Benefits have dwindled and the low pay is grating, realization of how much less benefits (and they cost more) we receive currently compared to 10 yrs ago. UIC is administration heavy compared to other Chicago colleges and Universities. Administrators want Faculty to bring in more research $$$, and then when they do, they lose 57+% to overhead but do they ever fix infrastructure? Heck No (despite having Excellent tradesmen on campus).  Administrators want Faculty to bring in more research $$$ then they insist Faculty teach more. Not exactly a recipe for top flight R1 school. Some senior professors who bring in No money do not realize that the UIC motto is not "the beatings will continue until morale improves" re. how they treat junior faculty.  Take your research money elsewhere Juniors, you can do it.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: Scientific inquiry, collaborative environment. No more positive things to say, so filling 20 word minimum with filler words and repetitive words and repetitive words.
cons: Tantamount to slave labor. The NIH model of research is wasteful while at the same time it manages to pay the bare minimum to researchers. Inefficient research and poor working conditions are emblematic of academia.

review_title: Good work for a sophomore in college
pros: You develop the skills necessary to skim through so many documents, and I will definitely apply those skills in school.
cons: It was a cubicle job, and working in that environment on a daily basis was a difficulty after a while.

review_title: I worked for campus housing so this isn't a review of UIC as a whole just that segment.
pros: Flexible hours,  free housing in the summer,  working with students,  not having to commute.
cons: Pay,  the work demand,  very stressful and it is placed on you

pros: They pay for your tuition when you're a TA

pros: University if Illinois at Chicago has liberal work conditions than other companies. The relationship between the employees within the organization is good.

less compensation than other companies
not much scope for further growth
unstable management
fluctuating rules and policies within the university of Illinois system

pros: People around are very helpful, but not very highly efficient. But generally it's a good place to start the career.

review_title: Great benefits but lots of politics with management depending on department.

pros: It is in the middle of chicago which is a really conveiniant and good location to work in. Good compensation.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chicago, IL

pros: If you are a student, they will always work around your schedule. Very friendly people who genuinely care about your success and future. Free advice all the time!

pros: Good student job, not too busy, nice bosses. The office is very relaxed, and the hours can be very very flexible.

job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in Chicago, IL

review_title: Great school with good student worker opportunities

review_title: good place to work, good work environment
